section.title: Introduction
section.p: Bitflux Editor has been developed originally by Christian Stocker and Roger Fischer from Bitflux GmbH. The project is hosted at http://www.bitfluxeditor.org.

section.title: Download via CVS
section.p: Bitflux Editor is included in the Wyona cvs. So you don't need to download it separately. If you want to be sure to use the latest version, you can get it from the Bitflux cvs:
section.source: cvs -d :pserver:anonymous@bitflux.ch:/var/lib/cvs/editor login Return cvs -d :pserver:anonymous@bitflux.ch:/var/lib/cvs/editor co example

section.title: Mozilla
section.p: You need at least Mozilla 1.0. If your Build ID is too old, then hope still exist by editing the javascript bxe/js/bitfluxeditor.js (navigator.productSub <= 20020523, BX_mozilla_version).

section.title: Getting Data from Server
section.p: The parameters can be configured within the file inc/config.xml
section.source:
<imput> <file name="BX_xmlfile" method="http" isParam="true">url-xml</file> <file name="BX_xslfile" isParam="true">url-xslt</file> <file name="BX_schemafile" isParam="true">url-xsd</file> </input>
<css><file isParam="true">url-css</file></css>
<output><file name="BX_posturl" method="wyona" isParam="true">url-post</file></output>
section.p: Beware that the MIME-TYPE for the schema file (xsd) is set properly by the server to text/xml. Wyona does that for you already, but in case you serve it via Apache you have to update Apache's config.

section.title: Posting Data to Server
section.p: To save the document the BitfluxAction is used. It is nearly the same as the XopusAction. The only difference is that the filename for saving is passed to the action as parameter. Although you could actually set the filename within the javascript bxe/js/wyona.js (BX_DocumentID) and then use the XopusAction.
